Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Optical Surface Studies of Iron and its Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Franz Geiger of Northwestern University to prepare and study films of iron and its oxides that are 100,000 times thinner than a sheet of paper. This approach makes it possible to literally shine light on important technological problems connected to iron, such as corrosion and environmental cleanup. By directly and indirectly interacting with students, teachers, lawyers, and policy makers, the Geiger group is also communicating science to the general public, specifically in the context of the Village of DePue, a superfund site located in the state of Illinois.

Iron and its oxides are dark and heat up upon light exposure. Therefore, it is difficult to study their surfaces with instruments that use light, such as a microscope or a laser, and the understanding of many technological applications involving the surfaces of iron and its oxides remains limited. The project invokes a concept that dates back to 1729, when it became clear that diluting colored solutions allowed increasing amounts of light to pass through them. Applying this concept to iron solids, the Geiger group researchers will prepare and characterize nanometer-thin films of iron and its oxides and study their dynamically changing chemical and structural responses upon contact with technologically relevant fluids using a variety of interface-specific laser methods. Special attention will be paid to determining mechanisms of surface passivation so as to develop methods for rejuvenating iron substrates that otherwise deactivate over time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award led to the development of nanometer thin chemically pure iron metal layers exhibiting novel properties, including hardness exceeding that of bulk metal iron and a propensity for energy harvesting from ionic solutions such as ocean water or bodily fluids. The project also resulted in the first atomic view of the iron:iron oxide interface, providing structural information important for mitigating corrosion and rust formation. Moreover, the project resulted in a fundamental advance regarding the mechanism for nonlinear optical signal generation from charged interfaces, which led to the development of an optical voltmeter, in which photons, as opposed to aligator clips, are used to measure electrostatic potentials from surfaces and interfaces.

The intellectual merit of the project includes the following:
First direct, atomically and speciation resolved structure of the iron:iron oxide interface;
First all-inorganic, single-element energy harvester prepared in a single step; and
First  heterodyne-detected second harmonic generation spectrometer 

The broader impacts activities of the project integrated its scientific activities centered on environmental interfaces with an Education and Public Outreach plan that included annual meetings at the Environmental Law and Policy Center, the Midwest’s largest organization of its kind, where the PhD students learned how their laboratory work connects to environmental policy decisions while providing scientific primers to the lawyers, thus expanding ELPC’s scientific knowledge base and deepening our insight into the shaping of environmental political and legislative strategies. An important outcome from this interaction is the Village of DePue superfund site project, which involved the Northwestern University Environmental Law Clinic, Chicago-based Groundswell Educational Films, two Evanston Township High School science teachers, and the two trainees on the project. The project is summarized in a 5-min short film available on YouTube that shows how well it worked to spark curiosity for science in the high school students

The results were disseminated in a series of freely available publciations, at international scientific conferences, in trade journals, video hosting serves, and in the popular press, including the BBC World Service and Smithsonian Magazine. The project resulted in two patents issued and two provisional patent applications. Two trainees received their PhDs this summer and are now working as a Linus Pauling Postdoctoral Fellow at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and as an Eric and Wendy Schmidt Science Postdoctoral Fellow at Harvard University.
